text.p: Despite being forced indoors by rain, Britain's Greg Rusedski did his pre-Wimbledon confidence no harm by winning the Nottingham Open on Saturday.
The Canadian-born Rusedski powered to an impressive 6-4 7-5 final victory over Karol Kucera and made it clear he was fed up with living in the shadow of British number one Tim Henman.

"Maybe I'll get a headline now," commented Rusedski after landing his fourth ATP title. "Even at Queen's it was What's wrong with Tim?' and not Rusedski's doing well'. The only way to do something about it, I guess, is to keep winning.

Torrential rain forced organisers to take the semi-finals and final of the grass-court tournament indoors for the second day in succession. As a consequence, 3,000 fans were again locked outside due to a lack of spectator access and safety reasons.
Another 100 watched from under umbrellas through the windows of the Nottingham Tennis Centre as Rusedski despatched Aussie Sandon Stolle 6-3 6-4 in the first semifinal.
Kucera then beat Henman 6-4 2-6 6-4 to rule out the unprecedented sight of two Britons contesting an ATP final.
